review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 3, 2019
review_body: There's no need to suffer through menopause!  I've used this Menopause Relief Herb Pac for years and it just plain works!  No hot flashes; no night sweats and no mood swings.  I have recommended it to other women for years, and every person has come back to me to thank me.

review_title: Works better than western herbs for me, but it is so dang expensive
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 27, 2017
review_body: This product helps with symptoms. Not 100%, but it does make a big difference.  Much, much better than other supplements I have tried e.g. black cohosh, chasteberry, dong quai, sage, soy, bioidentical progsterone. These other supplements have absolutely no positive effect. I checked with my naturopath, and she says that this Pacific Herbs formula works very well for some women. On the other hand, black cohosh, chasteberry, etc. work incredibly well for other women. You have to experiment to see which one works for you.This price is relatively high, I've seen it for between 40-55 dollars here on amazon.  I try to buy multiple bags when the price goes down. You have to order quickly since the price can easily go back up an hour afterward.I find this does not taste great as a tea, so I use the scoop to pour a dry dose in my mouth and then swallow with water. I don't mind the taste at all when the product is not in tea form, it has an herbal licorice flavor.-----------------Update: I was still taking this,, but I am so tired of paying 60 dollars a month ($720 per year). This is just too much to keep paying. I have recently started doing a castor oil pack every night and that takes away my hot flashes. Buying the castor oil is much cheaper than this formula, and it has additional benefits.

review_title: january 2016 - update:  worked initially as noted but after a few weeks back to night sweats, heat flashes.  Placebo effect?
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 11, 2015
review_body: Never wrote a review before but I am prompted to today because this stuff really works.  I am literally only on Day 4 of using this product and my excruciating night sweats have abated by reasonably more than 65%.  Before I started using this, my night sweats were waking me up every 2 hours all night long.  I'm down to 2 times since I started taking this.  I take it twice a day mixed with plain yogurt and honey since I heard the taste of this in a tea would not be pleasant.  The taste is accented mostly by the Stevia sweetener and the honey I use masks that.

review_title: Disappointed - didn't work for me and one pack isn't really one months worth
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2018
review_body: I have 10-20 hot flushes/night sweats per day so I needed to take the maximum dose. Which meant that one package was not enough for a month. After taking two packages worth (about 5 weeks worth aka more than $100), I didn't notice any benefits at all. Perhaps this works better for people with more mild symptoms. So, unfortunately I am still on the hunt for something to help me.

review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 22, 2014
review_body: I didn't buy this for menopause treatment, but as a natural mood leveler. It doesn't taste very good, but I can get it down if the water/tea is very hot, i feel it is very effective as a natural mood leveler when taken daily (I take it once a day). I also take it in conjunction with fish oil and vitamin B complex.**** updated April 2015. I still use this product occasionally and believe it works, but have to lower my review from 5 to 3 stars because of the crazy increase in price. In December 2013 (16 months ago), this cost $35 with Prime shipping on Amazon. Now it's $55!? That is much too large an increase for just over a year. I'm keeping my eyes open for more reasonable alternatives.

brand: Pacific Herbs
name: Natural Fertility Tea Herb Extract
features: Increase your chances of pregnancy with Fertility Tea Herb Pack. Formulated by a fertility doctor with over 30 years of experience, Fertility Tea naturally improves the body’s ability to produce high-quality eggs & prepares the womb to conceive. | Our re-sealable, stay fresh pouch of 100 grams or 3.5 oz of highly concentrated herbal extract usually lasts a month. Simply dissolve .5 to 1.5 tsp of granules in warm water & drink like a tea or place directly on tongue & swallow w/ water or juice. | Unlike other herbal & non-herbal fertility supplements out there, Pacific Herbs Fertility Tea Herb Pack does not contain fillers, binders nor any unnatural chemicals with hard-to-pronounce names. We only have pure, potent herbs grown in nature. | Our Fertility Tea has no unwanted side effects, is safe for long term use, and can be used in conjunction with IVF (in vitro fertilization); to further increase your chances of conception, be sure to get our Sperm Boost Herb Pack for your partner. | Pacific Herbs does NOT buy products that have been fumigated with sulfur dioxide (SD); we have stringent policies for raw herb sourcing of all our products, which are tested for potency & purity and traceable by LOT numbers on every package.
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 21, 2018
review_body: I swear this tea helped me get pregnant! This combined with acupuncture. I tried other fertility teas and many supplements for months and this one I took for only 2 months and got pregnant after my 2nd cycle. I think it also tasted amazing. To me it tasted like warm brown sugar water and it also helped my sex drive (sorry if TMI). My husband drank the mens tea the 2nd month only and that is the month we finally conceived, but it tasted way different... He just drank it quickly. I would highly recommend for anyone trying to conceive! Just make sure you are buying it from a reputable source.

review_title: No sides effect and taste great!
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 6, 2019
review_body: I will give 5 star for the good quality and taste of it ans 3 star because did not helped me to get pregnant like they said. I have been drinking this fertility tea for about 3 weeks and at the same time we are trying to conceive so we don’t know yet.I take this fertility tea and my husband takes the one called sperm boost the same brand is a blue bag. Usually one bag it will last for about a month. My second bag arrived!I wish to get pregnant. I will coming back writing an update here. (No sides effect for me).  Thanks to the Company that makes this tasty and healthy fertility tea herb.Update: not pregnant, after one month using this fertility tea. I will give 5 star when I will get pregnant. I just gain more weight and I feel more hungry every day. To be honest I don’t know what exactly does this tea to my body 😟 maybe good or maybe not good. I will using the second bag of the fertility tea and after that if don’t get pregnant I won’t buying it anymore. Sorry but I feel that it is just waste of money.

review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 22, 2020
review_body: I do not know if it works but I drink it as a tea before bedtime or sometimes a tspn full with water or whatever I am drinking. It tastes better in a warm tea though. Less potent tasting that way.Also, the bag was so small for that amount of money. However, the ingredients matched what I was looking for when it came to chinese herbs for fertility.I will update if I get a bfp this month.

brand: Pacific Herbs
name: Natural Sleep Supplement Herb Extract
features: iSleep Herb Pack contains 50 grams or 1.75 oz of concentrated herbal extract in granules and is based on a time-tested formulation that was originally written down over 800 years ago. iSleep only contains pure, potent herbs grown in nature. | iSleep works by gently relaxing your body and calming your active mind so you can fall asleep naturally, stay in deep, restful sleep and wake up alert without morning grogginess and other side-effects; also, there’s no risk of addiction with iSleep. | Take iSleep before bed if you have difficulty falling asleep or in the middle of night if you have trouble staying asleep. Dissolve .5 to 1.5 tsp of granules in warm water & drink like a tea or place directly on tongue & swallow with water or juice. | Many studies have shown that Chinese herbs can effectively manage sleeplessness, including an extensive one in Taiwan w/ over 16,000 participants, who had issues falling & staying asleep; Chinese herbs are time-tested & extensively clinically tested. | Pacific Herbs does NOT buy products that have been fumigated with sulfur dioxide (SD); we have stringent policies for raw herb sourcing of all our products, which are tested for potency & purity and traceable by LOT numbers on every package.
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 18, 2015
review_body: Love this tea, it is very relaxing and works very well to help fall asleep.  I use to take a prescription medication for those nights when I couldn't fall asleep but didn't like how they made me feel groggy in the morning so I tried this on a recommendation of a Holistic Nutritionist and was impressed at how well this product worked!  Without any side effects of course.  Tastes good, it comes in a packet that dissolves as opposed to a regular tea bag and it has a nice, mild flavor and dissolves easily.  Works better than a drug and I wake up refreshed because it has I think 12 healthy herbs to help you relax and get a good nights sleep.

review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2019
review_body: I have trouble  sleeping all the way through the night.  I'll wake up between 2 and 4 a.m. and be unable to get back to sleep.  For me, this product is the real deal. It reliably helps me go back to  sleep quickly and sleep until morning.  It takes effect in just a few minutes. You use a very small amount of product so this is more affordable than it might seem at first.  I have not tried to use it when I'm too tensed up to fall asleep at all.

review_title: Like most people the first few days are the worst ...
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 27, 2018
review_body: I suffer with severe and at times debilitating menstrual cramps and have tried numerous things that have not helped. I thought I would give this herbal packet a try because I prefer natural supplements over medications that can have many side effects and was pleasantly surprised with the result. Like most people the first few days are the worst pain wise for me and the first few days i tried this the pain was less severe. The taste was also much more pleasant than I expected and could enjoy having a warm tea like concotion of this in the morning. It isn't a miracle pack and can't take endometriosis level pain away in a second, but I do feel it has approved and has helped more the longer I've taken it so I think it would be worth a try for anyone considering this.

review_title: Acupuncture took the edge off and I do recommend it, but the pain was still there
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 13, 2017
review_body: If I could give this product a thousand stars, I would. I am now 44 and have suffered my entire life with DEBILITATING menstrual pain to the point of ending up in the ER SEVERAL times. About ten years ago, I was diagnosed with PCOS. It has been suggested, but never confirmed I also have endometriosis. I am very healthy otherwise, and have been vegan for 20 years as well as grain-free. Still, nothing has helped the extreme pain I've had to experience since I began menstruating some 30 years ago. Acupuncture took the edge off and I do recommend it, but the pain was still there. Motrin helped a little too, but made me experience abdominal pain (even though I only took one every 12 hours). And I really am not a fan of Western Medicine, except for emergency/trauma stuff. I have very short periods only lasting two days, but so much pain. Anyway, long story short. I was in my local health food store and asked (yet again) if they could recommend anything for SEVERE menstrual pain. They showed me this, and I bought. This is now my second cycle using this product, and my pain (normally a 10 plus) is about a 2, occasionally goes to a 4, but still manageable (without having to put crap [Motrin] in my body). MAJOR relief. I wish I'd known about this product YEARS ago. THANK YOU! THANK YOU! THANK YOU!!! I will continue to use this so long as I have a period.

review_body: My Chinese medicine practitioner recommend this product for my 3 teenagers. If they take it at first sign of symptoms, it helps substantially with:IrritabilityCrampingBreast tendernesBloatingHeadacheAll the yucks!However. Speaking of yucks, my daughters hate the taste. brand: Medicinal Plants of the Pacific Northwest: A Visual Guide to Harvesting and Healing with 35 Common Species
name: Medicinal Plants of the Pacific Northwest: A Visual Guide to Harvesting and Healing with 35 Common Species
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 18, 2024
review_body: I never review books but this book is so amazing I want everyone to know about it. And I want other authors to see how incredible it is! Why can’t all guidebooks look like this? So often I read about a wild plant and how to make medicine and it’s missing key information about how to process it. Also, in many foraging guides you can’t tell anything about who the plant is based on the images. This book is my dream, visually. It has not only pictures of leaves and flowers and even petals, it has seed pods at different stages of development and leaf shape variation when relevant. It’s so, so good. I bought it even though I won’t be living in the PNW soon.

brand: Pacific Northwest Medicinal Plants: Identify, Harvest, and Use 120 Wild Herbs for Health and Wellness (Medicinal Plants Series)
name: Pacific Northwest Medicinal Plants: Identify, Harvest, and Use 120 Wild Herbs for Health and Wellness (Medicinal Plants Series)
review_title: A useful reference book with some unexpected spiritual beliefs included
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 1, 2024
review_body: This book covers medicinal plants native to the Pacific Northwest. It starts out with a bit of pertinent information about foraging safety and best practices, and mixes in some of the author’s personal spiritual relationship with the plants. I have to admit I wasn’t expecting there to be a spiritual element to this book, but it doesn’t negatively impact the ability to use this book as a reference. This book also describes the various ways you can prepare your foraged medicinal plants for use. This section is particularly informative.After all of the pertinent foraging information is imparted, the book gets straight to the 120 wild plants, which are listed alphabetically. Each plant gets a breakdown including its common name, its scientific name, any other names it might be called, and what the plant is used for. Each plant also gets at least one picture. You learn how to identify your plant. You learn where/when/how to harvest it. You’re taught what each plant is used for, how to ensure a future harvest, and you even get a breakdown of how best to prepare your plant for its medicinal purposes. Do you use your cottonwood buds for a tincture? Do you use them for a salve? This book will tell you.The back of the book features a handy metric conversion chart, a list of references, and a helpful index that allows you to look up individual plants by name or by the ailment you’re hoping to relieve.It’s a data-packed book laid out in a fairly straightforward and thoughtful manner. Those curious about herbalism, foraging, or just native plants in the Pacific Northwest would really enjoy this. And for those not interested in the spiritual aspects discussed in this book, don’t worry. The author’s spirituality does not permeate the book in a way that negatively impacts its usefulness for plant reference.

brand: Pacific Northwest Medicinal Plants: Identify, Harvest, and Use 120 Wild Herbs for Health and Wellness (Medicinal Plants Series)
name: Pacific Northwest Medicinal Plants: Identify, Harvest, and Use 120 Wild Herbs for Health and Wellness (Medicinal Plants Series)
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 5, 2018
review_body: While it looks like a field guide, it's actually an informative reference for the casual herbalist. Scott Kloos includes a lot of personal experience and opinion, which is the reason to buy this book I think. If you're looking for any medicinal science information or a comprehensive field guide then look elsewhere. One feature this book has that I like is the helpful instructions for how to harvest sustainably and prepare different remedies such as tictures or teas.It has some spiritual themes which is why I give it 4 stars. I wanted a guide to herbs, their effects, and how to prepare them, not an introduction to your brand of spirituality.

brand: Pacific Northwest Medicinal Plants: Identify, Harvest, and Use 120 Wild Herbs for Health and Wellness (Medicinal Plants Series)
name: Pacific Northwest Medicinal Plants: Identify, Harvest, and Use 120 Wild Herbs for Health and Wellness (Medicinal Plants Series)
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 23, 2024
review_body: Wonderful information.

brand: Pacific Northwest Medicinal Plants: Identify, Harvest, and Use 120 Wild Herbs for Health and Wellness (Medicinal Plants Series)
name: Pacific Northwest Medicinal Plants: Identify, Harvest, and Use 120 Wild Herbs for Health and Wellness (Medicinal Plants Series)
review_title: My New Favorite Medicinal Herb Book!!
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 8, 2019
review_body: I just LOVE the way this book was written and the way the author conveys his kinship to the plant kingdom.  His introduction and explanation of how he got interested in the subject, and his description of his many years of working with medicinal herbs and wildcrafting, is reminicsent of own interest and enthusiasm.  I like the focus first and foremost on proper identification and the importance of having a minimal impact on the plants environments, when wildcrafting.  I also am happy to find a book with GOOD pictures and descriptions of what the plants really look like, in addition to describing the habitats where they might be found. Many of the herb books I have do not have pictures or drawings that really help identify the plants I am interested in finding.  I am carefully reading this book from cover to cover, and taking notes and doing drawings of my own, all BEFORE I venture out into the woods to try my hand at wild crafting.  I am glad to be getting back to my "roots", and regaining the knowledge, that was more commonplace years and years ago, of what the plants all around us can do for our bodies and spirits!

brand: Pacific Northwest Medicinal Plants: Identify, Harvest, and Use 120 Wild Herbs for Health and Wellness (Medicinal Plants Series)
name: Pacific Northwest Medicinal Plants: Identify, Harvest, and Use 120 Wild Herbs for Health and Wellness (Medicinal Plants Series)

review_body: Was able to pick this book up go in my backyard and identify plants, it’s insane how we were taught to demonize “weeds” and all along they had medicinal properties we were taught to see them as nuances instead of nourishment. Buy this book, learn the plants, teach the youth, and end this cycle let’s take back our health & our minds.

brand: Pacific Northwest Medicinal Plants and Herbs for Beginners: The Complete Guide to Identifying, Harvesting, and Preparing Medicinal Plants
name: Pacific Northwest Medicinal Plants and Herbs for Beginners: The Complete Guide to Identifying, Harvesting, and Preparing Medicinal Plants
review_title: A great introduction to wild medicinal plants in the Pacific NW
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 14, 2022
review_body: One of the things I appreciated about this book is that it provides an excellent overview of the topic for newbies, but also has enough depth for those who have some experience wildcrafting and working with medicinal plants. I enjoyed reading about best practices, safety, which plants you'll find each season, and how to harvest different parts.Chapter 4: Medicinal Plant Identification Guide, was my favorite part of the book because this can definitely feel overwhelming to someone just starting out. The info on botany/plant morphology was clear, useful and had just the right amount of detail to feel more comfortable with the terminology when learning to identify plants.The last section has a nice intro to some of the medicinal plants native to the Pacific NW, which can then be cross referenced in a field guide when hiking or exploring your neighborhood. A great book to learn about the many benefits of working with these amazing plants!

brand: Pacific Northwest Medicinal Plants and Herbs for Beginners: The Complete Guide to Identifying, Harvesting, and Preparing Medicinal Plants
name: Pacific Northwest Medicinal Plants and Herbs for Beginners: The Complete Guide to Identifying, Harvesting, and Preparing Medicinal Plants
review_title: Introductory guide for wildcrafting and PNW plants
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 20, 2022
review_body: General interest in wildcrafting and herbalism has dramatically grown in recent years, and in response so has the appearance of publications and education programs designed to satisfy the demands of those seeking to become more knowledgeable and to develop their skills in the field. Beginning this journey of learning can be overwhelming without solid resources. This self-published introductory guide to wildcrafting, herbalism, and medicinal plants of the Pacific Northwest is one of the more recent books to become available.The author endeavors to cover a broad foundation of concepts for those beginning to learn, including ethical harvesting, plant identification (including poisonous species), basic plant uses in herbalism, an overview of the history of herbalism and plant medicine, and highlighting a basic inventory of common plants that can be found in the Pacific Northwest. It should be noted that a number of the plants showcased in this book can also be found widely throughout North America.As a reviewer, my opinion is that this book is a good starting point for those who are unfamiliar with herbalism and field botany, however for gaining requisite skills and knowledge there is no substitute for spending time out in the field with an experienced botanist and/or herbalist. Learning plant identification is a life-long art, as is developing deep relationships with individual medicinal plants. This book would be a starting point for someone seeking to begin their plant journey.

brand: Pacific Northwest Medicinal Plants and Herbs for Beginners: The Complete Guide to Identifying, Harvesting, and Preparing Medicinal Plants
name: Pacific Northwest Medicinal Plants and Herbs for Beginners: The Complete Guide to Identifying, Harvesting, and Preparing Medicinal Plants
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 19, 2022
review_body: Love this book!  As new home/property owners we are trying to replant native trees, shrubs, and plants to bring a long ago clear-cut and bulldozed area back to life.  Learning about plants and herbs native to our area that we can incorporate into our Hedgerow and garden areas, AND also use medicinally, is very exciting.  The information and instruction given in this book will definitely be referred to often for years to come.

brand: Pacific Northwest Medicinal Plants and Herbs for Beginners: The Complete Guide to Identifying, Harvesting, and Preparing Medicinal Plants
name: Pacific Northwest Medicinal Plants and Herbs for Beginners: The Complete Guide to Identifying, Harvesting, and Preparing Medicinal Plants
review_title: Solid introduction to herbology and wildcrafting. Not a great PNW plant resource.
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 19, 2022
review_body: This book does a good job of detailing how and when to ethically harvest medicinal plants, and how to preserve and prepare them. It also describes 47 medicinal plants found in the PNW. Line drawings and written descriptions are provided for each species, as well as some basic botany to help in plant identification. Strangely the drawing for Thimbleberry appears to be a drawing of Trailing Blackberry, having the compound leaves with three leaflets of this related species rather than the simple five-lobed leaves of Thimbleberry. Overall the drawings do roughly emulate their subjects though. As a botanist I would be wary of beginners using these resources alone to identify plants for medicinal use, but in combination with a good field guide or two the resources provided would be useful.In terms of readability I found Boyle's prose to be a bit awkward at times. There doesn't appear to be an editor for the book, which does it a disservice. Nonetheless, the author's knowledge of and passion for herbology and wildcrafting make this book informative and engaging. I particularly appreciate his emphasis on ethical harvesting, and the gratitude and joy to be had from engaging directly with wild plants.

brand: Pacific Northwest Medicinal Plants and Herbs for Beginners: The Complete Guide to Identifying, Harvesting, and Preparing Medicinal Plants
name: Pacific Northwest Medicinal Plants and Herbs for Beginners: The Complete Guide to Identifying, Harvesting, and Preparing Medicinal Plants
review_title: Very informative and inspiring, easy read.
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 20, 2022
review_body: I thoroughly enjoyed this book. Ive been gaining interest in foraging medicinal plants to assemble my own natural apothecary at home. Perusing this book gave me confidence to continue to learn and pursue this passion. Pictures were clear but I would’ve enjoyed actual colored pictures. The importance of safety guidelines, wildcrafting, always bringing water on excursions was covered well. I would definitely recommend this book and will buy a copy.

brand: Pacific Northwest Medicinal Plants and Herbs for Beginners: The Complete Guide to Identifying, Harvesting, and Preparing Medicinal Plants
name: Pacific Northwest Medicinal Plants and Herbs for Beginners: The Complete Guide to Identifying, Harvesting, and Preparing Medicinal Plants
review_title: Enthusiastic guide to herbal wildcrafting in the PNW
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2022
review_body: There was a great deal in here about wildcrafting/wild herb harvesting that I have not read before. The author repeated safety warnings many times - which is good, considering how easy it can be to have a reaction to a plant or accidentally find a poisonous look-alike. There were times I found the writing a bit confusing or odd, but it didn't effect my overall reading enjoyment. The line drawings were interesting,  but I agree with another reviewer that having another resource to verify plants against would be a good thing,  because personally, I would rather have a color photo to compare the plant to than just a line drawing - it would help me feel more confident in my identification. Also, this book isn't about PNW native plants,  although it does mention some of them,  it is about medicinal plants (some of which are considered invasive in Washington state - like Herb Robert) that grow in the PNW, and I have to admit I was hoping there would be info on more of the truly native plants.

brand: Pacific Northwest Medicinal Plants and Herbs for Beginners: The Complete Guide to Identifying, Harvesting, and Preparing Medicinal Plants
name: Pacific Northwest Medicinal Plants and Herbs for Beginners: The Complete Guide to Identifying, Harvesting, and Preparing Medicinal Plants
review_title: Healing respecting earth and wild human nature
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 13, 2022
review_body: Sharing wildcrafting practices with beginners presents challenges well met by Rory Boyle. In addition to succinctly presenting safety info, such as the three most deadly plants (baneberry, poison hemlock, and water hemlock), he presents an ethos that is sustaining and helpful to habitat through nuanced gathering practices. For example, dandelion is so hearty you can feel free to harvest as much as you want, while endangered plants are off limits. Rory points to the needs for learning wild medicines as a form of reconnecting, healing ourselves as following our natural instinct. Enjoy taking this path, rewilding way of being!

brand: Pacific Northwest Medicinal Plants and Herbs for Beginners: The Complete Guide to Identifying, Harvesting, and Preparing Medicinal Plants
name: Pacific Northwest Medicinal Plants and Herbs for Beginners: The Complete Guide to Identifying, Harvesting, and Preparing Medicinal Plants
review_title: Go for a walk and learn a lot
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 22, 2022
review_body: This is an amazing book, especially for someone new to the area and interested in what is in the woods.  The book is organized is a manner that allows a novice to learn in small steps or can be used by the advanced citizen botanist for detailed information.  This book will stay on my phone so that I can check my pictures in my very own forest nearby as well as when we go off camping all over the state.

brand: Pacific Northwest Medicinal Plants and Herbs for Beginners: The Complete Guide to Identifying, Harvesting, and Preparing Medicinal Plants
name: Pacific Northwest Medicinal Plants and Herbs for Beginners: The Complete Guide to Identifying, Harvesting, and Preparing Medicinal Plants
review_title: Helpful book for beginners like me!
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 19, 2022
review_body: I am new to learning about medicinal plants and this book was so helpful. I enjoyed how the book went into great detail about identifying plants, I also found it really helpful to learn about the universal edibility test.Being from the PNW, I really liked how he highlighted each area and what edible plants the environment provided.If you love earth and want to participate in taking care of her and learning about edible plants, this is the book for you!

brand: Pacific Northwest Medicinal Plants and Herbs for Beginners: The Complete Guide to Identifying, Harvesting, and Preparing Medicinal Plants
name: Pacific Northwest Medicinal Plants and Herbs for Beginners: The Complete Guide to Identifying, Harvesting, and Preparing Medicinal Plants
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 28, 2022
review_body: I just started getting into plants and for a newbie, it’s nice having a book that isn’t overwhelming but instead has a decent amount of information. It’s also helpful knowing other uses for plants, so this medicinal book gave me a new way of looking Mother Nature!

brand: Medicinal Plants of the Pacific West
name: Medicinal Plants of the Pacific West
review_title: The best that I have found.
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 21, 2023
review_body: This book is well written.  Easy to understand and clear pictures is very nice.  The Author does not hold back with vey informative information.

brand: Medicinal Plants of the Pacific West
name: Medicinal Plants of the Pacific West
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 21, 2017
review_body:
I can't quit reading and rereading this book. A native Oregonian, I had no idea some of the so-called "weeds" on my property were not only edible, but also medicinal! This book has changed my way of looking at the plants I once ignored. I've tried several of the teas and concoctions. Great instructions! Inspiring. Easy to read -- I feel like the author's my new best friend.
  
Medicinal Plants of the Pacific West

brand: Medicinal Plants of the Pacific West
name: Medicinal Plants of the Pacific West
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 23, 2013
review_body: A thorough monograph of each species features complete descriptions for identification and collection, medicinal uses and preparation.  Range maps aid in understanding general locales, drawings are accurate and useful, text is based on a sound grasp of cell chemistry without overdoing the technicalities, and is relatively myth-dispelling.  Responsible and authoritative from a practical intimacy, this hands-on guide also provides a glossary and cross-references.  A valuable addition to the herbals shelf, it would be nice to see this volume as a spiral-bound guide for field use.  The best yet of Moore's well-devoted works in my library.

brand: Medicinal Plants of the Pacific West
name: Medicinal Plants of the Pacific West
review_title: A classic for herbalists on the West Coast
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 22, 2019
review_body: This is essential reading and reference for herbalists on the US west coast. I'm especially appreciative of the alcohol intermediary oil extraction method on page 25. It makes the most fragrant and deeply colored oils  (only good for certain herbs) in just 24 hours.

brand: Medicinal Plants of the Pacific West
name: Medicinal Plants of the Pacific West
review_title: The only thing I do not like and it is not just with this book but ...
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 14, 2016
review_body: I  have been looking for books on how to make medicines and identify plants. This book has been very helpful and I plan on buying more of his books. The book is well organized has some color pictures, location maps, line drawings, information on plant appearance, habitat, constituents, collecting and preparation, stability, medicinal uses and contraindications. It has a supplemental herb list, a theraputic use list, glossary and index of plant names.The only thing I do not like and it is not just with this book but with almost all of the plant idenification books, is that they do not have color pictures for all of the plants.They need that and when they do pictures they need the photos of all the plant parts. Many times drawings are just not good enough especially if you are new to this. The only reason for the four stars is the lack of color pictures.

brand: Medicinal Plants of the Pacific West
name: Medicinal Plants of the Pacific West
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 4, 2023
review_body: This is just what I wanted, very little wear, so great deal.

brand: Medicinal Plants of the Pacific West
name: Medicinal Plants of the Pacific West
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 18, 2013
review_body: We use to many drugs and if we took a moment to learn how to use the natrual medicinal plants we have we would do much better. We would save money and be much healthier. When we use what nature provides us it is much better for our bodies. This book will help you to learn how to use natures medicens to help us recover and we will not need to ingest checmicals. Take a look and even discuse it with your doctor. I believe this is an excellent book to help us return to the way the good Lord ment it to be using nature to cure out issues.

brand: Medicinal Plants of the Pacific West
name: Medicinal Plants of the Pacific West
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 15, 2010
review_body: Beyond useful. Packed full of information, sordid (but intriguing/useful & necessary) details that make clear what you want & need to know. The author is well studied & experienced on his subject & laces his work with humor that makes this book so much more fun to read & use. This book's value cannot be measured in monetary value. A must have essential for all herbalists, botanists/ethno-botanists & plant enthusiasts alike. 10 out of 5 stars.

brand: Medicinal Plants of the Pacific West
name: Medicinal Plants of the Pacific West
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 17, 2021
review_body: Lots of useful information in the plant monograph section to be sure. However, I am disappointed in the composition and format.  While there are photographs, certainly a feature necessary for me, they are in a "format explanation" section.  I wish they were right next to the plant in the monograph section.

brand: Medicinal Plants of the Pacific West
name: Medicinal Plants of the Pacific West
review_title: only a few color pictures mostly just drawings
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 8, 2021
review_body: Quite a few plants are mentioned but I was disappointed that there were not more color photos included. Was not impressed with the drawings. would not recommend this book for a beginners or those that do not know plants well.

review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 6, 2024
review_body: I do have to say that this book does have good information, however it was just disappointment for me from page one. I'm personally not a fan of the layout of this book as I find it difficult to find something specific. To me it appears like the whole book was copy and pasted and the pictures are low quality and black and white. Ive been going out in the lovely wilderness with another foraging book that I really like, and am successfully finding things while using it. I was looking for another book for cross referencing and maybe finding something else but the level of, I can only think, disappointment, I'll be continuing that look because I won't be taking this one with me. I consider it a complete waste of money and I'm sad.

brand: From Dirt to Plate: 121 Wild Edible & Medicinal Herbal Plants The Pacific Northwest Foraging Guide
name: From Dirt to Plate: 121 Wild Edible & Medicinal Herbal Plants The Pacific Northwest Foraging Guide
review_title: The perfect guide for a beginner to foraging!!
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 11, 2023
review_body: I am a beginner to foraging and after going through this book I couldn't be more excited to get out on a hike and try and identify some plants! I love in Colorado so this guide is perfect for me and since I love camping and hiking I'll definitely be carrying it around all the time! This guide provides you with EVERYTHING you need to know from the description of each plant to the habitat they grow in to the different edible and medicinal uses some of them may offer. One thing in particular I really enjoyed was there was a whole section going over toxic plants to be cautious of. I think this will be extremely useful for me when I'm exploring outside. I have the kindle version but I just ordered a paper back too!!!!! You definitely NEED this if your considering foraging for plant or if you already do this extensive guide will have you covered!!!

brand: From Dirt to Plate: 121 Wild Edible & Medicinal Herbal Plants The Pacific Northwest Foraging Guide
name: From Dirt to Plate: 121 Wild Edible & Medicinal Herbal Plants The Pacific Northwest Foraging Guide
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 8, 2023
review_body: I found this book very helpful as I am a beginner and I want to learn all I can before starting.  This book goes over everything from the tools that are helpful to toxic plants.  There are black and white pics of each plant and a detailed written description of each.  It goes over each plant and its medicinal and edible qualities.  I would take off half a star for spaces between each word is missing in alot of places but I was still able to read it pretty smoothly.  Also it would be great if the pics were in color, however with Google this isn't absolutely necessary.  All in all its a wonderful book to add to your collection of you're just now beginning to be interested in foraging plants!

brand: From Dirt to Plate: 121 Wild Edible & Medicinal Herbal Plants The Pacific Northwest Foraging Guide
name: From Dirt to Plate: 121 Wild Edible & Medicinal Herbal Plants The Pacific Northwest Foraging Guide
review_title: Very Useful Tool for the Outdoors
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 9, 2023
review_body: Overall, I found this book to quite eye opening and it had a lot of useful information in regards to identifying some wild plants. As someone who is still new to identifying various plants and foraging for them, this book definitely gave me a better understanding of what basic tools I would need to start foraging some of the various plants that are mentioned in the book. Additionally, this book also allowed me to learn about some of the benefits of foraging, that I had never initially knew about. This is definitely a useful book that a would recommend to anyone who is new to foraging and identifying wild plants!

brand: From Dirt to Plate: 121 Wild Edible & Medicinal Herbal Plants The Pacific Northwest Foraging Guide
name: From Dirt to Plate: 121 Wild Edible & Medicinal Herbal Plants The Pacific Northwest Foraging Guide
review_title: A Wonderful Reference for New Foragers or Pros.
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 9, 2023
review_body: Dirt to Plate is packed with a lot of useful tips for beginners to seasoned foragers. It contains extensive information about a variety of plants along with how to identify, harvest, and use. It also provides information on the risk of using different plants. If you are new to foraging, it is also great to get you acquainted on how to get started and the materials you will need. It is the PERFECT resource to carry on your foraging excursions.

brand: From Dirt to Plate: 121 Wild Edible & Medicinal Herbal Plants The Pacific Northwest Foraging Guide

review_body: I enjoyed reading and going through the entrys as they helped me understand that a lot of plants that grow in our part of the states are beneficial to us and are edible. With over 121 plants youll find plants that are medically healthy for us, while some can be critically dangerous. The book never feels boring with it's designs and representation of said plants. If your looking for a nice book on plants in the northeast this is for sure the book to go for!

review_body: I disliked this product. I've been buying and preparing sea moss for over a year. I purchased this brand by mistake but thought it would be the same.I soaked and rinsed it for up to 2 days but the sea moss never became soft or gel like. I prefer a more smoother texture.Next time I'll stick to what I always buy.

review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 10, 2023
review_body: This is the first time I am consuming this product. After watching a few YouTube videos, I decided to make a gel to be used in smoothies. Based on the color of this moss, it seems to be good quality. A very little (like 1/5th of this bag) makes a whole blender full of gel. You have to wash this very thoroughly. There was not much sand in it but there were some other type of algae attached to it (in tiny amounts, but needed to be cleaned). It is easier to clean them after soaking the moss for a while. So, I washed it and then put in water with some lemon juice for about 4-5 hours (unlike 12 hours to overnight as recommended on the listing). Though it has tones of yellow and red in dry form, most of it is gone after the wash and it turns into a pinkish white noodle-like form. There were some thick and hard parts and some soft parts. The latter more quickly softens and the hard pieces become like soft leather, but this doesn’t seem to matter. After putting the whole thing with some soak water in the blender, I got a pretty smooth and thick juice. I took a spoonful and I had no difficulty swallowing it. The gel has no smell or flavor to it. So, consider this as a neutral ingredient in whatever you are planning to make. This is just not your salad type algae, but it is pretty good for its suggested uses.

review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 1, 2023
review_body: I hadn't realize that there has been a lot of hype surrounding the nutritional benefits of using sea moss.  When I received, I really didn't know how to use; however, my daughter had picked some up at a health food store and realized (and after reading the Amazon home page for this item) that you place in water, blend and store in a refrigerator.  We've been using a scoop of this in our parfaits, smoothies or even in our tea.  I haven't been able to see any major improvements, but I do like the nutritional benefits it provides and have opted to use this instead of vitamin boosts.  Overall, would re-order.

If you want the benefits of sea moss this is a pretty good way to go.

review_title: Amazing product that helped cure my back pain and soreness
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 15, 2024
review_body: I spend over 15 hours a day working in front of a computer. For the past two months, I've been suffering from back pain and neck soreness due to a lack of exercise and, to be honest, not having time for it. My mom recommended this product to me, as she had used it before with great results. I was skeptical at first, but I finally decided to follow her advice and give it a try. I have to say, I was amazed. The minute I put it on, I felt an instant warmth and a refreshing mint-like sensation on my back. The best part is that my pain and soreness were immediately alleviated. After using the entire box over the course of a week, I felt significant relief from the pain. The experience was gentle and soothing, and I also really liked the herb-like scent. I think I'll definitely buy it again.

review_title: The first dry + wet combo I have ever seen in a pain relief patch
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 13, 2024
review_body: The patch contains a medicated core, yellow dry powder inside with a very strong herbal scent. The wetting bag is to moisten the powder, this is very special.Bought this because my massage therapist recommended it. He said this is a well known brand in China and is sold in many hospitals and clinics. Don’t know if it’s true but the effect was pretty good! Applied one patch on my neck the for one night. The heat from the patch made me feel very comfortable and the next day my neck felt a lot better.Also this tiggers my interest in Tibetan medicine. Searched about it a bit, was impressed by the long history and “balancing” philosophy of it. The natural herbal formula contains a blend of 6 plants, one of them is what we call Sichuan Pepper in daily life, another is the tumeric. I never knew these plants we use as seasonings have medical application, too!  Very interesting to know.

brand: The Homesteader Herbal Handbook: 5 Simple Steps to Grow, Harvest, and Store 25 Backyard Medicinal Herbs to Craft Your Own Natural Remedies (Growing Natural Remedies Series)
name: The Homesteader Herbal Handbook: 5 Simple Steps to Grow, Harvest, and Store 25 Backyard Medicinal Herbs to Craft Your Own Natural Remedies (Growing Natural Remedies Series)
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 25, 2022
review_body: The Homesteaders Herbal Handbook: 5 Simple Steps to Grow, Harvest, and Store 25 Backyard Medicinal Herbs to Craft Your Own Natural Remedies by Jenni Rempel is a very informative book that will delight even the staunchest of city folk.  Whether you have a lot of land or just a windowsill, with this book, you can help your own health and let's be honest, given the rising cost of modern pharmaceuticals, your wallet as well.  Ms. Rempel does include the reminder to check with your doctor before beginning this medicinal pursuit to help ensure your safety.  Various links are included to help expand your knowledge beyond the borders of this book. Modern medicine is still in its infancy compared to older established cultural practices such as Western Use, Ayurveda Medicine and Traditional Chinese Medicine and all three of the established practices have used herbs in the treatment of others for thousands of years and therefore, the benefits of the herbs should not be overlooked and if you're still doubting that, consider the fact that even the Father of Medicine himself, Hippocrates used these herbs and had listed 400 herbs for their medicinal properties in 5th century BC.Many of the herbs listed are ones that most people should be familiar with: Aloe Vera, Chamomile, Chili Pepper, Elderberry, Garlic, Ginger, Ginkgo, Lavender, Mint, Oregano, Parsley, Rosemary, Sage, St. John's Wort, Thyme and Turmeric. The others are Ashwagandha, Calendula, Echinacea, Hawthorn, Holy Basil, Hyssop, Milk Thistle, Moringa, and Valerian. Covered subjects with each of these herbs is planting, the needs of the individual herb, how to harvest it, the best way to store them and what you can do with each herb after it's been harvested plus potential side effects, correct dosage, the traditional and modern benefits, possible interactions with other medicines, and who shouldn't use it as an herbal medicine.The one section that stood out to me not just because it's always a good idea to have alternatives to how you take any medicine, be it traditional or modern, but because after reading through it, I ended up making a lot of these or at least those that I had the ingredients for was titled: “Putting those homestead herbs to good use with 16 simple recipes”. These recipes range from curry to whiskey and while not quite everything in between, you'll be hard pressed not to find at least one that you'll want to devour out of these mouthwatering recipes.

brand: The Homesteader Herbal Handbook: 5 Simple Steps to Grow, Harvest, and Store 25 Backyard Medicinal Herbs to Craft Your Own Natural Remedies (Growing Natural Remedies Series)
name: The Homesteader Herbal Handbook: 5 Simple Steps to Grow, Harvest, and Store 25 Backyard Medicinal Herbs to Craft Your Own Natural Remedies (Growing Natural Remedies Series)
review_title: Great for a beginner! Or anyone else on their homesteading journey.
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 25, 2022
review_body: I received the advanced copy link for the PDF version of this book about 2-3 weeks ago. I am an herbalism student, so I thought it would be helpful to tack this on for learning. It was quite helpful, as I did not inherit the gardening skills of my parents & grandparents. There are some nice tips in this book that I think will help out when I start to construct my pollinator, herbal/plant medicine, & vegetable garden out back. I've been actively trying to become a better DIY person for years. Just this year I dove in & started learning more with some local & online folks to forage, wildcraft, & homestead. This advanced copy was a great addition to my list of resources. There are some things I knew beforehand, as I've really only DIY'd with essential oils. Some recipes are very similar to what I've been doing for years. There are things I didn't know or hear about before. I'm hoping I can order a physical book, as the PDF version was a little hard to read with my eye issues. Sending it to my kindle finally worked. But the best viewing for this advanced PDF copy was the kindle app on my tablet. I've found out that PDFs show up differently & one doesn't have all the highlighting & note-taking capabilities compared to a digital book. I'm still one of those that cling to physical books, especially those for reference. This will be added to my physical library when I can afford it. I have enjoyed Jenni's emails & other sources of information since being introduced to her & her knowledge a few weeks ago. I'd definitely recommend it to a beginner. It appears to be laid out understandably. At least for me, who processes things a bit differently & might need a different way of learning than some other folks. I wouldn't call myself a beginner. Maybe more middle-of-the-road for some aspects, maybe an expert in others. But definitely a beginner as far as foraging, wildcrafting, & 90% of homesteading go.

brand: The Homesteader Herbal Handbook: 5 Simple Steps to Grow, Harvest, and Store 25 Backyard Medicinal Herbs to Craft Your Own Natural Remedies (Growing Natural Remedies Series)
name: The Homesteader Herbal Handbook: 5 Simple Steps to Grow, Harvest, and Store 25 Backyard Medicinal Herbs to Craft Your Own Natural Remedies (Growing Natural Remedies Series)
review_title: Must read, loads of information in an easily digestible way.
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 25, 2022
review_body: Before reading "The Homesteader Herbal Handbook," I had zero knowledge about herbs. To be honest, I only use pepper on my mashed potatoes and crushed red peppers on my pizza. Beyond that, I have never used anything else. Jenni Rempel, the author, does an excellent job of making the book easily digestible. It doesn't feel like you are reading a book at all. Instead, it feels like you are sitting down at a table, drinking coffee and talking about herbs and the benefits they can do for you, and how easy it can be to set up something to maximize the growth of these herbs. The book's format is easy to understand and comprehend from the front to the back, which optimizes the reading experience. It is a handbook. It'll serve beginners well and perhaps even keep seasoned pros on their toes. This book is very informational.Aside from the information, what this book does well, in the beginning, is it'll make you think. At the beginning of the book, the author dives into a few mysteries and the history of herbs. She attempts to answer the question 'can science and nature work together?', while "herbs have an incredible history but lack the volume of scientific studies to prove their benefits. Pharmaceuticals are still in their infancy compared with traditional medicine" (pg 19 of 166). I admire the attempt to wrestle with the question and give the best answer that can be given, the answer is both, and they need to work together in unity. The book is definitely worth the read.

brand: The Homesteader Herbal Handbook: 5 Simple Steps to Grow, Harvest, and Store 25 Backyard Medicinal Herbs to Craft Your Own Natural Remedies (Growing Natural Remedies Series)
name: The Homesteader Herbal Handbook: 5 Simple Steps to Grow, Harvest, and Store 25 Backyard Medicinal Herbs to Craft Your Own Natural Remedies (Growing Natural Remedies Series)
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 10, 2022
review_body: I was already interested in gardening and urban homesteading, and this book provides a handy overview of the benefits of a variety of medicinal herbs. At times I questioned how well researched it was, but if anything, that has piqued my interest in learning more. A good reference book for the price.

brand: The Homesteader Herbal Handbook: 5 Simple Steps to Grow, Harvest, and Store 25 Backyard Medicinal Herbs to Craft Your Own Natural Remedies (Growing Natural Remedies Series)
name: The Homesteader Herbal Handbook: 5 Simple Steps to Grow, Harvest, and Store 25 Backyard Medicinal Herbs to Craft Your Own Natural Remedies (Growing Natural Remedies Series)
review_title: Insightful for those interested in gardening !
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 28, 2022
review_body: The Homesteader Herbal Handbook is an essential guidebook to any greenthumbs trying to expand their backyard gardening or take it to the next level. The author, Jenni Rempel, has taken what can be a frustrating topic into an easy going, five step approach, filled with dos and don'ts, helpful tips on how to be successful.The book is an incredible resource, not just for outdoor plants but ones you can grow indoors. I was fascinated by the aloe vera chapter and will probably start growing my own in a windowsill. As it turns out, natural aloe vera is not green!! It is something companies add to their product in an effort to make it look more how we think natural aloe vera would look like.I love the homesteader approach to life. It is this rough enthusiasm for trying your best that appeals to me. I do backyard gardening and did not realize how much more I expand with different herbs that I had overlooked. Jenni really is through throughout her book on tips to help the plants live, what to expect along the way, what they can used for with natural or herbal medicine and what the science says on each. She strikes a good balance of, it is a good add on, not a replacement for modern medicine.I highly recommend this book to anyone who does backyard gardening, raised garden beds, has plants around the house or anyone who just wants to save a little money by growing something themselves.

brand: The Homesteader Herbal Handbook: 5 Simple Steps to Grow, Harvest, and Store 25 Backyard Medicinal Herbs to Craft Your Own Natural Remedies (Growing Natural Remedies Series)
name: The Homesteader Herbal Handbook: 5 Simple Steps to Grow, Harvest, and Store 25 Backyard Medicinal Herbs to Craft Your Own Natural Remedies (Growing Natural Remedies Series)
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 5, 2022
review_body: The Homesteader Herbal Handbook by Jenni Rempel is a wonderful book containing great information about herbs.The book starts out with the history of herbs.  There's details about the uses of herbs throughout history and so much more.  It was interesting too read the section about before pharmaceuticals, how our ancestors survived using plants, herbs, and spices.  They had to go by trial and error.  That was interesting to read.This book is full of useful and helpful information about herbs.  There were several herbs listed.  Many I had not heard of.  I like that the author listed some uses for each herb for example what the herb is used for, like anti-inflammatory or heartburn.The author includes information such as details about harvesting the herbs and how to make the most out of it.  That was really nice to read about.Some of the herbs listed are Aloe Vera, Elderberry, Ginger, Lavender, Mint, Hyssop, Rosemary, Sage, Turmeric,  Calendula, Garlic, and more.It is very interesting to learn information about different herbs and the uses for them.  The information is very helpful and useful.  I personally really like using herbs instead of regular medicine so it was really neat to learn about some new herbs.The information in this book is wonderful and very useful.  I really enjoyed it and highly recommend it.

brand: The Homesteader Herbal Handbook: 5 Simple Steps to Grow, Harvest, and Store 25 Backyard Medicinal Herbs to Craft Your Own Natural Remedies (Growing Natural Remedies Series)
name: The Homesteader Herbal Handbook: 5 Simple Steps to Grow, Harvest, and Store 25 Backyard Medicinal Herbs to Craft Your Own Natural Remedies (Growing Natural Remedies Series)
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 1, 2023
review_body: My sister grows herbs for spices, I want to for making my own remedies. With the high cost of medicine and the chemicals in them, I decided to learn more about growing herbs. This book explains the twenty-five most popular herbs used to make medicine. It describes the requirements you need to do for each plant, along with how to grow, harvest and store your herbs. You can make salve, teas, tinctures and more from herbs. I have made the spicy fruit smoothie and loved it, will definitely keep this book close.

brand: The Homesteader Herbal Handbook: 5 Simple Steps to Grow, Harvest, and Store 25 Backyard Medicinal Herbs to Craft Your Own Natural Remedies (Growing Natural Remedies Series)
name: The Homesteader Herbal Handbook: 5 Simple Steps to Grow, Harvest, and Store 25 Backyard Medicinal Herbs to Craft Your Own Natural Remedies (Growing Natural Remedies Series)
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 26, 2023
review_body: I LOVE fresh herbs but have not yet had any luck growing my own. We will not talk about the Chia Herb Garden fiasco of 2006. EVER. My family always had fresh mint and aloe when I was growing up and were frequently used for their healing properties. Aloe was for burns, mostly sunburns thanks to my Irish ancestors. Mint was excellent for making tea for an upset stomach. Reading 5 Simple Steps helped calm (some of) my black thumb nightmares, giving me a smidge of confidence to try growing my own aloe and mint. Maybe I'll add garlic and ginger since I use them so often while cooking.

brand: The Homesteader Herbal Handbook: 5 Simple Steps to Grow, Harvest, and Store 25 Backyard Medicinal Herbs to Craft Your Own Natural Remedies (Growing Natural Remedies Series)
name: The Homesteader Herbal Handbook: 5 Simple Steps to Grow, Harvest, and Store 25 Backyard Medicinal Herbs to Craft Your Own Natural Remedies (Growing Natural Remedies Series)
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 1, 2023
review_body: Have you been curious about where to start with herb gardening?  This book introduces you to the most common easy to grow herbs.  The author explains how to grow them, how to harvest them and shares both culinary and medicinal uses of herbs.  Recipes, usages, and very importantly cautions/contra indications are all discussed.  I was delighted to find reference to a library of full color pictures of the herbs discussed in the book available by qr code or going to a specific related website.  As I plant my garden this year this book will be a helpful tool!

brand: The Homesteader Herbal Handbook: 5 Simple Steps to Grow, Harvest, and Store 25 Backyard Medicinal Herbs to Craft Your Own Natural Remedies (Growing Natural Remedies Series)
name: The Homesteader Herbal Handbook: 5 Simple Steps to Grow, Harvest, and Store 25 Backyard Medicinal Herbs to Craft Your Own Natural Remedies (Growing Natural Remedies Series)
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 7, 2022
review_body: We have a small family farm and I’m a gardener with a growing interest in herbal remedies. I like the design of the chapters and the focus on easily obtained herbs with the inclusion of some less common herbs. It was definitely accessible and I appreciated the dosage info when available.I would have loved an reverse index by medicinal benefit, so I could easily find which herbs are recommended for respiratory ailments for example, rather than having to flip through the chapters to find that info again.All in all, a great beginner tome, and one I’m sure I’ll use as a reference in the future.

review_title: An honest review ! My first review on amazon ever
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 8, 2022
review_body: So its my first ever review on amazon. I am not a fan of writing reviews but i just need to tell you guys about this tea. As u can see on the pic - this is what i received! I paid for a medium size tea for sleep . And they sent me a cute letter with my name saying that they multiplied my tea in size and also gifted me a small bag of peppermint tea on top of that. Also they included couple of beautiful post cards. I felt so appreciated as a customer! Not saying that the tea itself smells as a fresh fields of mountain area… it made me sleep as a baby in just 5 mins! I am struggling with a severe anxiety and ptsd. So when i am saying “sleep like a baby”- it means a world to me. I was having serious issues with my sleep ,nightmares and insomnia… and this herbs made me have a wonderful restful night! My husband also took a cup of this blend and was sleeping amazing as well. It tastes very very pleasant!So if u struggle with a healthy sleep or anxiety or any hard period of life when your nerves need a support - try this.Again- i am amazed !! And the customer appreciation is beyond perfect!

brand: Frontier Co-op
name: Frontier Co-op Bulk Peppermint Leaf, 1 Pound, Cut, Sifted Peppermint For Tea & Cooking, Cool, Refreshing Scent
features: Cut and sifted; Non-irradiated; Botanical name: Menthe x pipe Rita | Non-Irradiated | Frontier is a member owned Co-op, responsible to people and planet
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 30, 2024
review_body: I love this loose tea! Not only do you get a huge bag of tea, but it is wonderful, strong, and fresh-tasting. I use one tablespoon for 32 oz of water, and I love how refreshing it is. I use my large glass Pyrex measuring cup with a little fine mesh strainer to make enough for myself and my wife.It has become our nightly ritual, replacing alcohol after a long day. Feel better and far less expensive than bourbon!

brand: Frontier Co-op
name: Frontier Co-op Bulk Peppermint Leaf, 1 Pound, Cut, Sifted Peppermint For Tea & Cooking, Cool, Refreshing Scent
features: Cut and sifted; Non-irradiated; Botanical name: Menthe x pipe Rita | Non-Irradiated | Frontier is a member owned Co-op, responsible to people and planet
review_title: Delicious, Refreshing Peppermint Tea- Perfect For Summer Tea Blends!
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 30, 2017
review_body: I wish this bag had a way to be resealed after opening. But it doesn't. I have to use a rubber band around it to try to keep it closed. It's odd that something like herbal tea leaves would not come in a closable container.Other than the inconvenience of that, this big ol' bag of organic peppermint leaves smells pretty amazing and tastes great. As soon as you open the bag, the strong minty, menthol aroma fills your nasal passageways and actually helps to clear them.It's potent, and the taste is surprisingly refreshing. At least it was surprising to me... I'm not used to drinking minty teas, and this one makes a delicious, bold tea with a slight tinge of sweetness and grassiness. You can smell that in there. It's more complex in aroma than one miggt expect.I like to mix it with organic raspberry leaves, organic elderberries & organic calendula flowers. But it really adds a perfect touch to herbal teas that are lacking in that little something, lacking in taste, in that pizzazz.Peppermint tea gives you a very cool and refreshing feeling, making it perfect for summer get-togethers, it gives you energy, and helps ease feelings of nausea. It's also known to give you mental alertness and clarity. This stuff is pretty powerful but not overwhelming in any way.If infused, the peppermint extract can be applied to sore muscles for some relief. You can blend with Arnica montana, Comfrey & Calendula as well, which are great for conditioning skin, healing bruises, and relieving soreness, stiffness and pain.I'm pleasantly pleased with this large bag of organic peppermint leaves, and I have so many plans for it! It really does inspire great ideas, and I decided to get the Spearmint leaves from Frontier as well. I promise to let you know how that goes!

brand: Frontier Co-op
name: Frontier Co-op Bulk Peppermint Leaf, 1 Pound, Cut, Sifted Peppermint For Tea & Cooking, Cool, Refreshing Scent
features: Cut and sifted; Non-irradiated; Botanical name: Menthe x pipe Rita | Non-Irradiated | Frontier is a member owned Co-op, responsible to people and planet
review_title: Better than other brands I've tried
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 9, 2023
review_body: I previously bought 1 lb bags of peppermint and spearmint tea from Davidson's and U.S. Wellness. Although they have a strong scent in the bag, the had almost no flavor, and definitely no flavor that I could identify as mint. The Davidson's spearmint was so powdery that it leaked out of the tea ball. This Frontier Co-Op bulk peppermint tea is an improvement on both fronts. First, the leaves are cut to the right size and don't leak out of the tea ball. Second, it has a strong minty smell and actually tastes like peppermint. I don't use any type of sweetener, which limits the taste. That's why I only give it 4 stars overall. With some sugar, it should be a great tea. Davidson's peppermint tea has gone up to almost $23 for 16 oz. Frontier Co-Op is $16 as of this writing. It's a no-brainer at that price difference. Note that I previously bought Davidson's spearmint, not peppermint, but based on the price I would not opt for Davidson's peppermint either.

This variety kit contains annual, biennial, and perennial herbs and flowers that are known for their medicinal benefits and healing properties. Occasional substitutions with appropriate replacements may occur due to shortages. | Medicinal Herb Starter Pack - From leaf to flower to root, the different parts of these plants can be used in many different ways. Create your own mixed tea from dried or fresh herbs. Use the raw ingredients to extract your own essential oil and create herbal tinctures, infusions, salves, lotions, balms, and ointments. | Sustainable Living - This essential seed collection is a must-have for any homesteader, prepper, naturalist, or survivalist who wants to become more self-reliant! This home apothecary in a bag gives you control, letting you grow an organic, wholesome garden to create your herbal treatments the right way. Many of these plants are ideal for container gardening, in hydroponic systems or growing indoors. | Easy to Grow - The seeds are packed in a beautiful paper packet with instructions for successful growing and germination in your home garden. Each package also has instructions for saving seeds after harvest. Getting started is simple for both beginner and experienced gardeners. | Quality Seeds - Plant now or store for future growing seasons. These seeds will remain viable for years if stored in a cool dry location. Our safe, non-hybrid non-GMO heirloom seeds are always open-pollinated, untreated, and selected to ensure the best germination rates.
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 28, 2024
review_body: This California heat has made it harder to grow, I will wait till it cools off a bit to plant the rest.

brand: The Complete Book of Herbs: A Practical Guide to Growing and Using Herbs
name: The Complete Book of Herbs: A Practical Guide to Growing and Using Herbs
review_location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 27, 2008
review_body: This is a simply marvelous book. It is a mystery to me why it is not continuously in print. Do not hesitate to buy this used from Amazon Marketplace sellers, as I did.The book is large and beautifully fashioned and produced, with gorgeous full-color photographs not only of each herb, but of dozens of different species of each herb, and of every possible use to which herbs can be put. There are full-color pictures of crafts, teas, household items, massage how-to illustrations, dyes--to say nothing of prepared food dishes; this is actually a cookbook within an herbal!ONE CAVEAT: if you are looking for an in-depth gardening how-to, with exhaustive planting info, you might want a supplement for this book, which sticks to the basics. But every other herb-related topic is embellished and elaborated on. There are dozens of pages with full-color, labeled illustrations of different "theme" gardens you can plan. Whole chapters EACH on potpurri, herbal cosmetics, dyes, medicines, and household cleaners. Fabulous, unique homemade gift items like herbal-scented beads--that's right, painted beads made entirely out of herbs and plants!The food/cooking section alone is worth the price of the book. The dishes are fantastic. I have already made the Sweet Rosemary Slices and several teas and drinks, and they are wonderful. Almost every recipe has a full-color photo.I could go on and on, but rather than waste your time, I will leave you to hit "Add To Shopping Cart."Money has rarely been this well-spent.

brand: The Complete Book of Herbs: A Practical Guide to Growing and Using Herbs
